unknownDevice.title: Unknown Device Detected
unknownDevice.description: You've discovered an unidentified device on your network. This could be a forgotten gadget, a guest's device, or something suspicious.

investigate.label: Investigate further
investigate.feedback: Good choice! Before taking action, it's wise to gather more information. Check your router's admin page to see when this device connected and look for patterns in its behavior.

block.label: Block it immediately
block.feedback: Blocking unknown devices can be appropriate, but doing so without investigation might disconnect a legitimate device you forgot about (like a smart plug or guest's phone). Consider investigating first.

ignore.label: Ignore it
ignore.feedback: Ignoring unknown devices is risky. It could be a neighbor stealing your Wi-Fi, an attacker, or forgotten smart device with security vulnerabilities. Always investigate unfamiliar devices.

packetJourney.title: Packet Journey
packetJourney.selectDevice: Select a device to trace its packet journey

idle.link: Ready to trace packet journey using MAC addresses
idle.network: Ready to trace packet journey using IP addresses
idle.transport: Ready to trace packet journey through ports
idle.application: Ready to trace packet journey at application level

deviceToRouter.link: Packet leaves device with source MAC to Router MAC as destination
deviceToRouter.network: Packet carries source IP (device) to destination IP (internet server)
deviceToRouter.transport: Data sent from random high port to destination port (e.g., 443 for HTTPS)
deviceToRouter.application: Application sends HTTP/HTTPS request through socket

routerProcessing.link: Router receives frame, strips MAC header, reads IP destination
routerProcessing.network: Router performs NAT: replaces private IP with public IP for internet
routerProcessing.transport: Router tracks connection state for return traffic mapping

routerToInternet.link: New frame created with Router WAN MAC to ISP Gateway MAC
routerToInternet.network: Packet now has public IP as source, routes through internet
routerToInternet.transport: Port mapping stored so response can find original device
routerToInternet.application: Request reaches destination server (website, API, etc.)

internetResponse.link: Response arrives at router's WAN interface from ISP
internetResponse.network: Response addressed to router's public IP, port identifies flow
internetResponse.transport: Server responds on established connection (same port pair)
internetResponse.application: Server sends response data (HTML, JSON, file, etc.)

routerBack.link: Router rewrites destination MAC to original device's MAC
routerBack.network: NAT reversal: replaces public IP with device's private IP
routerBack.transport: Original source port used to deliver to correct application
routerBack.application: Response delivered to waiting application on device

complete.link: Journey complete - device received response via MAC addressing
complete.network: Journey complete - private IP successfully communicated with internet
complete.transport: Journey complete - full request/response cycle through ports
complete.application: Journey complete - application received server response

privateIp.question: Which of these is a private IP address?
privateIp.explanation: 192.168.x.x addresses are private - they only work inside your home network. 8.8.8.8 is Google's public DNS, and 203.0.113.12 is your public IP (how the internet sees you).

macPurpose.question: What is a MAC address (Local ID) used for?
answers: Identifying devices on the local network
macPurpose.explanation: MAC addresses are hardware identifiers used for local delivery - like apartment numbers within a building. They don't leave your local network.

guestNetwork.question: Why would you put guests on a separate network?
answers: To give them faster internet speed
To prevent them from accessing your personal devices
Because there's a limit to devices on one network
guestNetwork.explanation: Guest networks create isolation. Visitors can use the internet, but they can't see or access your personal computers, cameras, or smart devices.

unknownDevice.question: You notice an unknown device on your network. What should you do?
unknownDevice.explanation: Unknown devices could be forgotten gadgets, neighbors leeching Wi-Fi, or even malicious actors. Check your router's admin page to identify and remove suspicious devices.

iotIsolation.question: Why are IoT devices (cameras, thermostats) often put on a separate network?
answers: They're often insecure and could be used to attack other devices
iotIsolation.explanation: Many IoT devices have weak security, use default passwords, or don't get updates. Isolating them prevents a compromised camera from spying on your laptop.

tenNetwork.question: What type of IP address range is 10.0.x.x?
answers: Private IP range for internal networks
tenNetwork.explanation: 10.0.0.0/8 is one of three private IP ranges (along with 172.16.x.x and 192.168.x.x). These addresses work only inside your network and can't be reached directly from the internet.

wpa3.question: Why does the staff network use WPA3 while guest uses WPA2?
answers: WPA3 is slower, only staff can handle it
WPA3 provides stronger encryption for sensitive data
wpa3.explanation: WPA3 offers better protection against password guessing attacks and uses newer encryption. Corporate data deserves the strongest protection available.

printerRisk.question: Why is the printer flagged as a security risk?
answers: It still has the default password, making it easy to hack
It's connected to the wrong network
printerRisk.explanation: Printers with default passwords are often targeted by attackers. They can be used to intercept documents, spread to other devices, or even become part of botnets.

corpIsolation.question: Why can't customers on guest Wi-Fi access the file server?
answers: The file server is turned off
Guest network is isolated from corporate network
corpIsolation.explanation: Network segmentation means different networks can't communicate. Guests get internet access but are completely walled off from internal resources.

openWifi.question: What does 'Open' network security mean?
answers: Anyone can join without a password
The Wi-Fi signal is publicly visible
openWifi.explanation: Open networks have no encryption. This means anyone nearby can potentially see your traffic - it's like sending postcards instead of sealed letters.

evilTwin.question: What is an 'evil twin' attack?
answers: A fake Wi-Fi network that mimics a legitimate one
When two routers interfere with each other
evilTwin.explanation: Attackers set up fake access points with names like 'Hotel_Free_WiFi' to lure victims. When you connect, they can see everything you do.

httpsImportance.question: On public Wi-Fi, why is HTTPS especially important?
answers: HTTPS encrypts your data so others on the network can't read it
httpsImportance.explanation: HTTPS creates an encrypted tunnel between you and the website. Even if someone captures your traffic, they see gibberish instead of your passwords.

vpn.question: What does a VPN do on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Creates an encrypted tunnel for all your traffic
vpn.explanation: A VPN encrypts everything leaving your device, not just web traffic. It's like putting all your postcards in a locked box before sending them.

safeBehavior.question: What should you avoid doing on public Wi-Fi?
answers: Logging into your bank without a VPN
safeBehavior.explanation: Sensitive activities like banking should wait for a secure network or require a VPN. Even HTTPS can't protect against all attacks on compromised networks.
